RandomAccessStream-0.1: Infinite lists with quick access to elements by indexSource codeContentsIndex

Description

Using traditional, linear streams, definind in Data.Stream as 

 Stream a = Cons a (Stream a)

requires O(n) time to access the nth element. This module offers Data.RandomAccessStream.Stream, taking O(lg n) time to access the nth element, but O(lg n) time to perform a cons.

Of course, streams are infinite, so it is not clear what it means to take O(f(n)) time to perform an operation at the head of the stream. We can instead give the cost of an operation as the number and location of new thunks introduced.

For instance, the cons operation on simple lists: 

 cons x xs = x:xs

puts one thunk between the 0th element and the rest of the list.

On the other hand, the cons operation for random access streams puts one thunk before each element at position 2^i-1. If x is a random access stream with no thunks in the first 2^i-1 elements, traversing them (using fromList, for instance) takes O(2^i-1) time. If, before traversing these elements, we call cons, the traversal takes O(2^i-1+i) time. This is longer than the time taken if we were to have used a linear steam: O(2^i).

On the other hand, looking up or modifying the element at location i takes only O(lg i) time. These operations take O(i) time on a traditional linear stream.

Documentation
data Stream a Source
Constructors
Stream a (Stream a) (Stream a)

Basic Functions
(++) :: [a] -> Stream a -> Stream aSource
(+++) :: [a] -> Stream a -> Stream aSource
cons :: a -> Stream a -> Stream aSource
O(lg n). Adds an element onto the head of the Stream. If the first n elements of a stream x are already forced, traversing the first n elements of (cons y x) takes O(n + lg n) time. The new thinks are just before the elements at positions 2^i-1, counting from 0.
head :: Stream a -> aSource
O(1). The first element in a stream.
tail :: Stream a -> Stream aSource
O(lg n). Removes an element from the head of the Stream. If the first n+1 elements of a stream x are already forced, traversing the first n elements of (tail x) takes O(n + lg n) time. The new thunks are just before the elements at positions 2^i-2, counting from 0.
Transformations
map :: (a -> b) -> Stream a -> Stream bSource
intersperse :: a -> Stream a -> Stream aSource

O(lg n) thunks at positions 2^i-4. Inserts an element between every pair of adjacent elements in the input stream. 

 intersperse y x == interleave x (repeat y)
interleave :: Stream a -> Stream a -> Stream aSource

O(lg n) thunks placed at positions 2^i-4. interleave x y creates a stream that alternates between the values in x and y, starting with x. 

 interleave (fromList [0,2 ..]) (fromList [1,3 ..]) == fromList [0..]
intercalate :: [a] -> Stream [a] -> Stream aSource
O(|result|) thunks, O(1) at each element of the result. intercalate x y concatenates the elements of y, using x as glue. Every place where two lists form y are joined, x in inserted.
transpose :: Stream (Stream a) -> Stream (Stream a)Source
O(n) thunks, O(1) at each element of the result.
Special folds
concat :: Stream [a] -> Stream aSource
O(n) thunks, O(1) at each element of the result. See Data.List.concat.
concatMap :: (a -> [b]) -> Stream a -> Stream bSource
O(n) thunks, O(1) at each element of the result. See Data.List.concatMap.
Building streams
iterate :: (a -> a) -> a -> Stream aSource
Forcing n elements of the result traverses O(n) thunks, O(1) at each element of result. The passed function is called n times.
repeat :: a -> Stream aSource
O(1). Turns a value into an stream containing only that value.
cycle :: [a] -> Stream aSource
O(1) thunk at each element of result stream. Fails if argument is the empty list.
Scans
scanl :: (a -> b -> a) -> a -> Stream b -> Stream aSource
O(n).
scanl1 :: (a -> a -> a) -> Stream a -> Stream aSource
O(n).
Unfolding
unfoldr :: (c -> (a, c)) -> c -> Stream aSource
O(n).
Sublists and substreams
Finite approximations
upTo :: Integral x => x -> (x -> a -> b) -> Stream a -> [b]Source
Cuts a stream down to the given size by taking some limited number of elements from that stream, then recursively cutting them down to size. If i<=0, returns the empty list.
compareUpTo :: (Integral x, Ord a) => x -> Stream a -> Stream a -> OrderingSource
Compares two streams up to the given depth. If the returned value is EQ, this does not indicate that the streams are equal, only that they do not differ up to the given depth. If the returned value is LT or GT, then the whole streams do, in fact, have that ordering.
compareUnequal :: Ord a => Stream a -> Stream a -> OrderingSource
Given two unequal streams, returns their ordering.
equalUpTo :: (Integral x, Ord a) => x -> Stream a -> Stream a -> OrderingSource
See compareUpTo.
Extracting sublists and substreams
everyNth :: Integral x => x -> Stream a -> Stream aSource
Returns every nth element. I'm not sure of the exact time complexity, but it gets a speedup from every power of 2 that divides n. I suspect the time complexity is O(e + r*m) where n is r * 2^e and m elements of the result stream are forced.
take :: Int -> Stream a -> [a]Source
O(n). Turns the first n items into a list. Returns the empty list if n<=0.
drop :: Int -> Stream a -> Stream aSource
See dropWithCons.
dropWithCons :: Int -> Stream a -> Stream aSource

If you drop m items and inspect n items from the remaining stream, dropWithCons takes

  • O(lg (m-1+n) + lg (m-2+n) + . . . + lg n) time for the m calls to tail that construct the dropped list and advance to the head of the remaining list.
  • no time to construct the remaining stream.

Doing so by turning it into a linear stream, then turning it back into a RandomAccessStream, as in drop takes

  • O(m) time to construct the dropped list and advance to the head of the remaining stream.
  • O(n) time to construct the remaining RandomAccessStream.

When n is much larger than m, dropWithCons may be the faster choice. If n and m are close, drop might be faster.

See Data.List.splitAt for functionality. For complexity, see note at dropWithCons.

See complexity note at dropWithCons.

See Data.List.dropWhile for functionality. For complexity, see note at dropWithCons.

See complexity note at dropWithCons.
span :: (a -> Bool) -> Stream a -> ([a], Stream a)Source
See Data.List.span for functionality. For complexity, see note at dropWithCons. Note that inspecting the Stream in the result will fail if the predicate is True on all items in the stream.

See complexity note at dropWithCons.

See Data.List.break for functionality. For complexity, see note at dropWithCons. Note that inspecting the Stream in the result will fail if the predicate is False on all items in the stream.
breakWithCons :: (a -> Bool) -> Stream a -> ([a], Stream a)Source
See complexity note at dropWithCons.

See Data.List.stripPrefix for functionality. For complexity, see note at dropWithCons.

Predicates
isPrefixOf :: Eq a => [a] -> Stream a -> BoolSource
Searching
lookup :: Eq a => a -> Stream (a, b) -> bSource
Returns the first b correspinding to an a equal to the given argument. If there is no such equal key, this function never returns.
find :: (a -> Bool) -> Stream a -> aSource
Returns the first value in the Stream for which the predicate is True. If there is no such value, this function never returns.
filter :: (a -> Bool) -> Stream a -> Stream aSource
Returns only the values for which the predicate is true. There must be an infinite number of these, or some inspectinos of the result will not terminate.
partition :: (a -> Bool) -> Stream a -> (Stream a, Stream a)Source
Indexing
(!!) :: Stream a -> Int -> aSource
O(lg i). Find the element at index i. Calls error and shows i if i<0.
adjust :: (a -> a) -> Int -> Stream a -> Stream aSource
O(lg i). Changes the value at position i by applying function f. If i < 0, does nothing.
elemIndex :: Eq a => a -> Stream a -> IntSource
elemIndices :: Eq a => a -> Stream a -> Stream IntSource
findIndex :: (a -> Bool) -> Stream a -> IntSource
findIndices :: (a -> Bool) -> Stream a -> Stream IntSource
Conversions
fromList :: [a] -> Stream aSource
O(n). Inspection of the result will fails if the argument is not infinite.
toList :: Stream a -> [a]Source
Extracts a list from a random access stream. For some constant c, places no more than c thunks at each node in the result.

union :: Eq a => Stream a -> Stream a -> Stream aSource
union does not behave the same way as Data.List.union, by necessity. union eliminates all duplicatees, whether in the first or second argument.
intersect :: Eq a => Stream a -> Stream a -> Stream aSource
